Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 08:21PM Peppi1 wrote: I have a strong family history of breast cancer and a fibroadenoma as well. It's my understanding that after a certain age, a fibroadenoma that is growing is usually removed. As you age, it should get smaller if anything. So the fact that it's getting larger is just a little red flag. I apologize, but I can't recall now after which age it should shrink and not grow. The size of mine is monitored. Plus if it's growing,  I think it can block the view on imaging of a potential cancer...so it will help future imaging tests if it's out. Wishing you all the best.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2009 09:33PM Peppi1 wrote: I am not well versed in radiology, but I do believe that mammogram and ultrasound can miss things. In fact, at the bottom of every report I have received is a disclaimer saying they can miss something and the percentage of time it can miss something. As far as I am aware, no one radiologic diagnostic tool is relied upon due to this. I had a mammogram and ultrasound that needed to be "reconciled", they didn't match so to speak..Dr. was hoping the ultrasound would give additional info, but it didn't.

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 04:13AM Peppi1 wrote: Tammy66- Do you know what yor BiRads score is on your mammogram report? Posts.Title: Ultrasound - False negative? Tammy66 mawhinney

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2009 06:41AM Peppi1 wrote: Hmmm...the BiRads is rating system..there is usually a BiRads number on a mammogram report..if you have a copy of the report it should be on there..at least the 2nd report..it's a number from 0 thru 5. So the Dr. the receptionist put you through to was the radiologist or your Obgyn? You may consider calling your Obgyn and letting her/him know what your thoughts are since that is the person that ordered the tests. It's always good to follow through if you feel uncomfortable. You don't want to walk away with a question mark. At the very least someone needs to explain to you what exactly was seen on the mammo..what it means ect..Sounds like no one really has done that yet (?)....It's so important to have a radiology facility that you have confidence in ..and once you find it..stick with them for each screening or whatever else you have done...let us know what happens...
Posts.Title: Ultrasound - False negative? Tammy66 mawhinney

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 08:14PM Peppi1 wrote: You know, when you have a scare like this..the spook of it can stick with you for a bit even after you are told all is well. You need to know there is NO question that it is really B9...sometimes you need to hear it more than once and maybe from more that one person. It's kind of like...you are sure it's B9 right?? You are certain, right??? It think if you go to the Breast Center to get their opinion you can accomplish 2 things. One..hear an expert tell you all is well to further ease your mind..and two, you can follow up there if there should be any issues down the road that need to be checked out. They will have your past records. The important thing is that you trust your Dr. First time around it can be hard to do that. I use the Dr.'s my family members have used..so I have much faith in them..I have seen them in action, I know they are good. I trust them. So when I got a call saying my results were B9, I could simply breath a sigh of relief, smile and move on. I hope you find this same thing in a Dr.
